awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project to explore the best way to document the development of the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, a story of diverse people drawn together for an adventure of exploration and discovery.  Rubin Observatory makes possible a critical mass of character-driven science documentary programming that will allow audiences to see themselves reflected in diverse members of the Rubin team.  A continuing web series will provide Rubin scientists and engineers with media training to tell their stories, thus broadening participation, increasing STEM enrollment, boosting scientific literacy, and increasing trust in scientists.  The full series will be developed through the early concepts created by this award.  It will create a model for employing women-led, diverse, local crews; for documenting “big science” through construction and integration, and for addressing the humanities in science documentary projects.  It will provide scientists with media training, and filmmakers with science training.  There will be an associated web series that will reach people all over the world, enabling everyone to avoid isolation and explore the universe, providing perspective for all human activity, and wordlessly confirming that ‘we are all in this together.’

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Vera C. Rubin Observatory is a 1.5 billion dollar project funded by the NSF and the DOE,  to conduct a 10-year wide, fast and deep optical survey of the Universe. It is a system of hardware and software designed to make new information available to researchers. It will have the world's fastest telescope mount, the world's largest camera, a frictionless mount, and unerring precision. It will publish 10 million alerts each night of changes in the sky. It will complete a survey of the sky every four days, repeat frames 1000 times and add the repeated images to concentrate light from the faintest objects including nearby asteroids and distant galaxies. Rubin is a discovery machine.
The PI makes science documentaries and has been researching and developing a documentary project about Rubin since she was awarded a competitive AURA contract to film the Rubin construction site on Cerro Pachon, Chile in 2017.  The EAGER award, in 2021 allowed her to hire crew and to film two years of construction, to build relationships and access, and to produce a character-driven, free web series that immerses audiences in the construction of what aims to be the greatest astronomical observatory ever.
 Rubin Documentary Project is a character-driven, process documentary project following scientists and engineers using math and building technology, in this case an impressive, ambitious system for space exploration.   It is the first comprehensive documentary audio/visual archive produced following the construction and integration of any astronomical observatory.  It is the first documentary project to film Chilean engineers's building an observatory in Chile in the seventy years since the founding of the European and the US southern observatories. It shows the diversity of   technical experts that are essential to this big science experiment, including cleaners, and refrigeration technicians, administrators, engineers and scientists. The construction process breaks the science down into its technical specifications making it accessible, preparing audiences for  operations.
It is a multilingual series because Rubin is a partnership between the US & Chile, and a global project in construction and operations.  There are precedents in science fiction and television sit-coms for the use of multiple languages. Star Wars and Star Trek feature characters who speak different languages, and treat the challenges of communication between cultures as part of the story. In the comic-telenovela, Jane the Virgin, a multi-generational family in Miami switches fluidly between Spanish and English.
The creative team is women-led, bi-lingual, and composed of women and men from North and South American.
Rubin Observatory makes it possible to produce a three-year documentary series following a team of STEM specialists doing something untried and challenging. It offers a further ten years of stories following operations, teams of scientists exploring and making discoveries that will win some Nobel Prizes.
The people hired to build such one-of-a-kind billion dollar facilities are good role models. They are good at their jobs, at communicating, and at working in teams. But the challenges are enormous. They are doing something they have never done before, and their work is dramatic.
Rubin Observatory is investing a significant part of its operations budget in education and public outreach.  It hired experts and developed educational resources for teachers, students, and non-scientists. Rubin's investment frees the documentary project to focus on the strengths of its medium, engaging audiences emotionally. 
The calibre and volume of story-telling possible with Rubin will allow audiences to imagine themselves as part of the team, expose them to the language and culture of the project,  and prepare them to join operations as students, future STEM professionals and as citizen scientists.
Science collaborations will post projects on the Zooniverse citizen science platform and  benefit from millions of people contributing to data analysis.

The goal of the documentary project then is to leverage the qualities of Rubin Observatory to include everyone in the exploration, discovery and stewardship of our world and our Universe.
It aims to serve all of the strategic goals of the NSF: broaden participation, increase enrolment in STEM, boost scientific literacy, and trust in scientists.
